pyantarctica.dataset¶

This module contains main functions to deal with dataframes and small processings.

pyantarctica.dataset.add_datetime_index_from_column(df, old_column_name, string_format='%d.%m.%Y %H:%M:%S', index_name='timest_')[source]¶

Convert a column in a dataframe df to a datetime element and move it as index of the df. The string_format rule specifies how the raw string is formatted.

Parameters:
  • df – dataframe of the original data
  • old_column_name – column containing the raw datetime string to be converted
  • string_format – how the string is organized
  • index_name – new column to add with datetime, and moved as index
Returns:

dataframe with datetime index named index_name
pyantarctica.dataset.add_legs_index(df, **kwargs)[source]¶

Add a leg identifier (defaults to [1,2,3]) to a datetime indexed dataframe of ACE measurements

Parameters:
  • df – datetime indexed dataframe to which add the leg index
  • kwargs – contains options to override defaults:
leg_dates : array indicating beginning and end (columns) of time period belonging to a leg / subleg (number of rows equals number of legs / sublegs)
codes : list indicating what code to use to denote legs. Defaults to integers in range [1,2,3,…] with 0 indicating out-of-leg datapoints
Returns:dataframe with a new column “leg” indicating to which leg the datapoint belongs to
pyantarctica.dataset.filter_particle_sizes(pSize, threshold=3, window=3, mode='mean', save='')[source]¶

Function to filter particle size distribution dataframes, where rows are datetime index entries and columns are subsequent, as given by the instrument, particle size bins.

Parameters:
  • pSize – datetime indexed dataframe of all particles. I think should be in dN/dlogD
  • threshold – check for a multiplicative increase, given by expected_value * threshold
  • window – size of the square moving windows to retrieve statistics, see ret_neigh()
  • mode – string specifying how to compute value to threholds: ‘mean’: the expected value is the mean of the values in the window. ‘std’ returns the standard deviation and ‘any’ all the values (to implement original filtering method)
  • save – if string is presented, save csv at this pointer
Returns:

filtered particle dataframe, with same datetime index as pSize
pyantarctica.dataset.generate_particle_data(data_folder='../data/', mode='all', data_output='./data/intermediate/', savedata=False, filtering_parameter=3)[source]¶

Utility to get aggregated aerosol data and store it in a df where columns are the different accregation. This function recomputes directly from locally stored filtered particle size data the aggregations. This function assumes that the folder structures are fixed.

Parameters:
  • data_folder – pointer to data top directory
  • data_output – where to save aggregated dataframe
  • mode – what to read and how:

| ‘all’ : all particle data in columns (small particles single bins and >400, >700 nm) | ‘single_bins’ : only single bin data (without accumulated >400 and > 700nm) | ‘aggregated’: all particle data aggregated in superbins (with >400,>700 nm) | ‘aggregated_no_noise’ : as ‘aggregated’ but without noisy bins

Parameters:
  • filtering_parameter – used to define which filtered data to read (see filter_particle_size threshold): 3, 5, 10 : the larger, the more permissive
  • savedata – boolean, store locally (in ./data/intermediate/) a copy of the assembled file
Returns:

datetime-indexed dataframe with particle sizes as columns

Todo

remove data folder structure assumption. Or actually rethink the whole function.

Todo

actually maybe better to deprecate the whole function and prepare a notebook preparing the data directly, maybe easier for renku inclusion. Even better, a big script preparing the different datsets.

pyantarctica.dataset.parsetime(x)[source]¶

Function to format timestamps to HH:MM:SS

Parameters:x – string containing badly formatted timestams
Returns:nicely formatted timestamp string
pyantarctica.dataset.read_standard_dataframe(data_folder, datetime_index_name='timest_', crop_legs=True)[source]¶

Helper function to read a *_postprocessed.csv file, and automatically crop out leg 1 - leg 3, and set as datetime index a specific column (or defaults to the standard)

Parameters:
  • data_folder – from where to read the *_postprocessed.csv datafile
  • datetime_index_name – specify non-default datetime index column (= timest_)
  • crop_legs – boolean to specify whether to remove data outside leg 1 to leg 3
Returns:

dataframe containing the original data, leg-cropped (if option active)
pyantarctica.dataset.read_traj_file_to_numpy(filename, ntime)[source]¶

Read air mass trajectory files as provided in project 11 – read them from trajetories/lsl folder

Parameters:
  • filename – file to be parsed
  • ntime – numer of backtracking time points (i.e. how many rows per trajectory to read)
Returns:

traj_ensemble, a datacube containing N_trajectories x M_backtracking_time_intervals x D_variables_model_out
Returns:

columns : name of D_variables_model_out (variables provided by the lagranto model)
Returns:

starttime : beggining of the backtracking time series in the ensemble
pyantarctica.dataset.retrieve_correlation_to_particles(data, particles, var, legs=[1, 2, 3], plots=True)[source]¶

Retrieve correlation to the whole series, and, if legs are specified, to independend legs.

Parameters:
  • data – dataframe of data, from which a column will be picked (var) and used to compute correlations to particle data
  • particles – dataframe containing different particle sizes bins, to which compute correlation with data
  • var – string indicating name of the data column to use
  • legs – IDs of the legs in which you want to computer correlations
  • plots – If True, plot the barplots indicating amount of correlations
Returns:

dictionary containing correlations to particles, figure (no handles returned, get them via plt.gca, plt.gcf and so on)
pyantarctica.dataset.subset_data_stack_variables(data, varset, seatype='total', mode='subset')[source]¶

Subset variables of a dataset stack. This function is just a shorthand to not have to specify all vaiables when subsetting dataframes. Not the most clever way to deal with this honestly.

Parameters:
  • data – dataframe of data to subset
  • varset – keyword specifiying the subset to get
  • seatype – defaults to total. When “wave” parameters are to be retrieved, specify which kind of sea parameters to have
  • mode – subset : return actual dataframe or returnnames: return only column names per subset
Returns:

either dataframe of data, or list of columns names.
pyantarctica.dataset.ts_aggregate_timebins(df1, time_bin, operations, mode='new', index_position='middle')[source]¶

Outer merge of two datatables based on a common resampling of time intervals:

Parameters:
  • df1 – datetime indexed dataframe to resample
  • time_bin – aggregation time, in minutes
  • operations – dictionary containing a suffix to add to the column name (empty to keep same name in the returned df) and operation used to aggregate entries in the df. Example {‘_min’: np.nanmin, ‘_max’:np.nanmax} returns a dataframe with columns ‘%colname_min’ and ‘%colname_max’, where %colname is the original column name.
  • index_position – position of the new timestamp index wrt to the resampling : ‘initial’, ‘middle’ or ‘final’
Returns:

resampled dataframe with uninterrupted datetime index and NaNs where needed
Example:

operations = {‘_min’: np.min , ‘_mean’: np.mean, ‘_max’: np.max, ‘_sum’: np.sum} df_res = dataset.ts_aggregate_timebins(df1, 15, operations, index_position=’initial’) print(df_res.head())
